title: Introduction to dfoliatR
text: dfoliatR currently CRAN. install dfoliatR use devtools package: installed, dfoliatR can called like R package

title: Introduction to dfoliatR
text: dfoliatR requires two independent datasets: Host data: Standardized ring-width series one individual trees (site series, multiple cores per tree need averaged tree level). average cores obtain individual tree series, see dplr::treeMean, use ARSTAN output files (.TRE) summary chronology tree. Non-host control data: Usually standardized tree-ring chronology (site chronology, individual tree series) non-host tree species. Alternatively, independent annually-resolved climate series. host non-host data formatted R match dplR::rwl object type. Data provided dfoliatR demonstrate utilities dfoliatR, courtesy Dr. Ann Lynch. first collection Douglas-fir trees sampled reconstruction western spruce budworm. paired ponderosa pine non-host chronology nearby site. host non-host objects directly dplR form rwl objects: dfoliatR package also includes second site users explore: data created presented vignette available package object names used .

title: Introduction to dfoliatR
text: Analyzing insect outbreak signals tree rings dfoliatR requires two-step process. Identify defoliation events host trees removing growth pattern non-host trees. Host non-host trees presumed respond similarly climate, step produces individual tree-level series two species share common. Composite host individual tree series site level assess scale defoliation. Events recorded threshold number /percentage trees (e.g., 25%) considered outbreaks. identify defoliation events, input set host tree series non-host chronology defoliate_trees() function. parameters regarding length severity growth departure can changed user. parameter defaults follow OUTBREAK (negative departures 8 years, least one reaching -1.28 standard deviations, allowing 1 positive excursion greatest departure). Definitions function parameters provided ?defoliate_trees best way evaluate results call defoliate_trees graph resulting “defol” object:  horizontal line plot provides measured time sequence tree. Defoliation events shown thicker line segments, colors indicate relative severity event. Breakpoints distinguish severe, moderate, minor defoliation levels can set via breaks parameter plot plot_defol. Basic informative tree-level statistics regarding sample data defoliation events provided. important note dfoliatR distinguishes “defoliation event” recorded individual trees “outbreak” synchronously effected proportion trees. Outbreak periods can identified function outbreak(). essence, composite function combines trees provided “defol” object assess synchrony scale defoliation. enough trees record defoliation (regardless duration), termed “outbreak”. Filtering parameters control percent trees defoliation minimum number trees required considered outbreak. Running outbreak produces new class data frame, “outbreak” object. “defol” objects, can plotted directly, summary statistics available.  summary statistics “outbreak” objects include identified outbreak event row, start/end years, duration, metrics used analyses. One important metric analyze return interval outbreaks. Many researchers use first year event point reference. One can calculate return intervals DMJ site way via
code: dmj_defol <- defoliate_trees(host_tree = dmj_h, nonhost_chron = dmj_nh,        duration_years = 8, max_reduction = -1.28, list_output = FALSE) plot(dmj_defol) defol_stats(dmj_defol) dmj_obr <- outbreak(dmj_defol, filter_perc = 25, filter_min_series = 3) plot_outbreak(dmj_obr) dmj_obr_stats <- outbreak_stats(dmj_obr) head(dmj_obr_stats) dmj_interv <- diff(dmj_obr_stats$start)  # All intervals dmj_interv #> [1] 73 72 24 32 78 28  # Mean interval mean(dmj_interv) #> [1] 51.16667  # Median interval median(dmj_interv) #> [1] 52

title: Authors and Citation
text: Chris Guiterman. Author, maintainer. Ann Lynch. Author. Jodi Axelson. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Guiterman C, Lynch , Axelson J (2020). “dfoliatR: R package detection analysis insect defoliation signals tree rings.” Dendrochronologia. doi:10.1016/j.dendro.2020.125750.
code: @Article{,   title = {dfoliatR: An R package for detection and analysis of insect defoliation signals in tree rings},   author = {CH Guiterman and AM Lynch and JN Axelson},   journal = {Dendrochronologia},   year = {2020},   doi = {10.1016/j.dendro.2020.125750}, }

what: Detection and Analysis of Insect Defoliation Signals in Tree Rings
title: Detection and Analysis of Insect Defoliation Signals in Tree Rings
text: goal dfoliatR provide dendrochronologists tools identifying analyzing signatures insect defoliators preserved tree rings. methods employs closely follow (cases exactly replicate) OUTBREAK, FORTRAN program available Dendrochronological Program Library. using dfoliatR publication, please cite paper: Guiterman, CH, Lynch, JN Axelson (2020) dfoliatR: R package detection analysis insect defoliation signals tree rings. Dendrochronologia. DOI: 10.1016/j.dendro.2020.125750.

title: Detection and Analysis of Insect Defoliation Signals in Tree Rings
text: can install released version dfoliatR CRAN : development version GitHub :

title: Detection and Analysis of Insect Defoliation Signals in Tree Rings
text: package requires users input two sets tree-ring data: standardized ring widths individual host trees standardized tree-ring chronology local non-host tree species climate series. dfoliatR combines remove climate signal represented non-host chronology host tree series. ’s left represent disturbance signal. dfoliatR identifies defoliation events host tree series. recommend input tree-ring data standardized either ARSTAN dplR R package. one ring-width series tree, standardized averaged tree level. ARSTAN, make sure output ‘.TRE’ files read R read.compact() function dplR. choose standardize raw ring widths dplR detrend(), use treeMean() function generate tree-level series. data input dfoliatR needs rwl object defined dplR.

title: Detection and Analysis of Insect Defoliation Signals in Tree Rings
text: briefly explore defoliation outbreaks patterns Douglas-fir site New Mexico. data included package start , identify defoliation events individual trees,  scale outbreaks compositing across site via
code: library(dfoliatR) ## load the data data("dmj_h") data("dmj_nh") ## Identify defoliation signals dmj_defol <- defoliate_trees(host_tree = dmj_h, nonhost_chron = dmj_nh)  ## Plot the results plot_defol(dmj_defol) ## Identify site-level outbreak patterns dmj_obr <- outbreak(dmj_defol)  ## Plot those results plot_outbreak(dmj_obr)

title: Detection and Analysis of Insect Defoliation Signals in Tree Rings
text: Analyses tree series (termed defol objects) can done via: plot_defol() defol_stats() get_defol_events() sample_depth() identify ecologically-significant outbreak events, use outbreak() function. Various filters available aid users defining outbreak thresholds. Analyses outbreak series (termed obr objects) can done via: plot_outbreak() outbreak_stats() full range usage dfoliatR, please visit introduction vignette.

what: Identify defoliation events in host trees — defoliate_trees
title: Identify defoliation events in host trees — defoliate_trees
text: defoliate_trees() starting point analyses insect defoliation signals preserved growth patterns trees. requires individual-tree standardized measurements potential host trees tree-ring chronology nearby non-host species. First, defoliate_trees() combines tree-ring indices calling gsi() perform "correction" host-tree indices remove climatic influences tree growth represented non-host chronology. isolate disturbance-related signal. Second, defoliate_trees(), runs id_defoliation(), completes runs analyses evaluate sequences negative departures host tree growth series (ngsi) potential defoliation events.

title: Identify defoliation events in host trees — defoliate_trees
code: defoliate_trees(   host_tree,   nonhost_chron = NULL,   duration_years = 8,   max_reduction = -1.28,   bridge_events = FALSE,   series_end_event = FALSE,   list_output = FALSE )

title: Identify defoliation events in host trees — defoliate_trees
text: host_tree dplR::rwl object containing tree-level growth series host trees compared non-host chronology. nonhost_chron dplR::rwl object containing single non-host chronology. blank, defoliation events inferred host_tree series provided. incumbent user ensure host_tree series properly prepared analyses nonhost_chron provided. duration_years minimum length time tree considered defoliation. max_reduction minimum value ngsi required considered defoliation event. sequence negative ngsi values reach threshold, potential event rejected. Defaults -1.28. bridge_events Binary, defaults FALSE. option allows successive events separated single year bridged become one event. used cautiously closely evaluated ensure likelihood two () events actually one long event. series_end_event Binary, defaults FALSE. option allows user identify event occurring time sampling defoliation event, regardless duration. Including help quantify periodicity extent outbreak. used user direct knowledge ongoing defoliation event trees sampled. list_output Defaults FALSE. option output long list object containing separate data.frame series host_tree includes input series nonhost_chron, corrected series, character string identifying defoliation events.

title: Identify defoliation events in host trees — defoliate_trees
text: default returns long-form data frame tree-level growth suppression indices identified defoliation events. list_output = TRUE, returns list object element containing data.frame rwl object host non-host series, plus outputs gsi(). list object useful assessing effects running gsi() host nonhost data.

title: Identify defoliation events in host trees — defoliate_trees
text: functions dfoliatR, like outbreak() plot_defol(), require long-form data frame identifiable defol() object. Selecting list_output = TRUE trigger errors running functions.

title: Identify defoliation events in host trees — defoliate_trees
code: # Load host and non-host data data("dmj_h") # Host trees data("dmj_nh") # Non-host chronology  dmj_defol <- defoliate_trees(dmj_h, dmj_nh)

what: Calculate the growth suppression index — gsi
title: Calculate the growth suppression index — gsi
text: function removes nonhost growth signal host tree-ring series.

title: Calculate the growth suppression index — gsi
Calculate the growth suppression index — gsi
text: input_series dplr::rwl object host tree series first column non-host chronology second. Years row names. specifically created defoliate_trees() passed gsi().

title: Calculate the growth suppression index — gsi
text: data frame two input columns (host nonhost series) 3 added columns: mean/sd adjusted non-host chronology, growth suppression index ("gsi") host series subtraction adjusted nonhost chronology, normalized growth suppression index ("ngsi") generated applying scale() gsi.

title: Calculate the growth suppression index — gsi
text: growth suppression index (GSI) referred "corrected" series OUTBREAK. calculated : $$GSI() = H() - (NH() - mean(NH)) sd(H)/sd(NH)$$ H NH host nonhost tree-ring series standardized index values; year, functions mean() sd() applied common period. gsi() rarely run directly user. called defoliate_trees().

what: Identify defoliation events in a host series — id_defoliation
title: Identify defoliation events in a host series — id_defoliation
text: calculating growth suppression index gsi(), id_defoliation() performs runs analysis normalized growth suppression index, ngsi, sequences negative departures assessed possible defoliation events. id_defoliation() workhorse defoliate_trees(), performing much necessary criteria evaluation used OUTBREAK. defaults parameters originate OUTBREAK. Two new features distinguish dfoliatR version: bridging events occur close sequence allowing recent end series evaluated defoliation regardless event duration. See parameter specifics details.

title: Identify defoliation events in a host series — id_defoliation
code: id_defoliation(   input_series,   duration_years = 8,   max_reduction = -1.28,   bridge_events = FALSE,   series_end_event = FALSE )

title: Identify defoliation events in a host series — id_defoliation
text: input_series data frame 5 columns, generated gsi(). duration_years minimum length time tree considered defoliation. max_reduction minimum value ngsi required considered defoliation event. sequence negative ngsi values reach threshold, potential event rejected. Defaults -1.28. bridge_events Binary, defaults FALSE. option allows successive events separated single year bridged become one event. used cautiously closely evaluated ensure likelihood two () events actually one long event. series_end_event Binary, defaults FALSE. option allows user identify event occurring time sampling defoliation event, regardless duration. Including help quantify periodicity extent outbreak. used user direct knowledge ongoing defoliation event trees sampled.

title: Identify defoliation events in a host series — id_defoliation
text: performing runs analyses, function adds column input data frame distinguishes years defoliation maximum defoliation year (ie. year greatest negative growth departure within event).

title: Identify defoliation events in a host series — id_defoliation
text: id_defoliation() called defoliate_trees(). might used user troubleshooting.

title: Constructor for an obr object. — obr
code: obr(   year,   samp_depth,   num_defol,   perc_defol,   num_max_defol,   perc_max_defol,   mean_gsi,   mean_ngsi,   outbreak_status )

title: Constructor for an obr object. — obr
text: year n-length numeric vector observed years. samp_depth n-length numeric vector number trees. num_defol n-length numeric vector number trees experiencing defoliation. perc_defol n-length numeric vector percent trees experiencing defoliation. num_max_defol n-length numeric vector number trees experiencing maximum level defoliation (.e., extreme negative growth departure). perc_max_defol n-length numeric vector percent trees experiencing maximum level defoliation (.e., extreme negative growth departure). mean_gsi n-length numeric vector average growth suppression index across observed trees. mean_ngsi n-length numeric vector average normalized (scaled) growth suppression index. outbreak_status n-length factor character vector identified whether year surpasses designated thresholds "outbreak event". Threshold criteria provided outbreak().

title: Constructor for an obr object. — obr
text: obr object columns matching input variables.

what: Composite defoliation series to determine outbreak events — outbreak
title: Composite defoliation series to determine outbreak events — outbreak
text: outbreak() takes defol object defoliate_trees() composites site-level object. Function parameters allow user filter tree-level series various ways optimize thresholds constitutes "outbreak" level event recorded host trees.

title: Composite defoliation series to determine outbreak events — outbreak
Composite defoliation series to determine outbreak events — outbreak
text: x defol object filter_perc minimum percentage defoliated trees considered outbreak. Default 25 percent. filter_min_series minimum number trees required outbreak event. Default 3 trees. filter_min_defol minimum number trees recording defoliation event. Default 1 tree.

title: Composite defoliation series to determine outbreak events — outbreak
text: data.frame obr object site includes trees host defol object. Columns obr include: year every year set host trees, num_defol number trees recording defoliation event, percent_defol percent trees recording defoliation, num_max_defol number trees recording maximum growth suppression (peak event tree), perc_max_defol percent trees maximum defoliation, mean_gsi average trees growth suppression index (gsi), mean_ngsi average trees normalized growth suppression index (ngsi), outbreak_status whether year constitutes outbreak based filters applied function.

title: Composite defoliation series to determine outbreak events — outbreak
code: data("dmj_defol") head(outbreak(dmj_defol)) #>   year samp_depth num_defol perc_defol num_max_defol perc_max_defol mean_gsi #> 1 1675          2         0        0.0             0              0   1.5303 #> 2 1676          2         0        0.0             0              0   1.2435 #> 3 1677          2         1       50.0             0              0   0.9222 #> 4 1678          2         1       50.0             0              0   0.9716 #> 5 1679          2         1       50.0             0              0   1.1373 #> 6 1680          3         1       33.3             0              0   0.7244 #>   mean_ngsi outbreak_status #> 1    1.5145         not_obr #> 2    0.7143         not_obr #> 3   -0.1820         not_obr #> 4   -0.0442         not_obr #> 5    0.4198         not_obr #> 6   -0.7303        outbreak

title: Outbreak statistics — outbreak_stats
text: data frame descriptive statistics outbreak event determined outbreak(), including: "start" -- first year outbreak "end" -- last year outbreak "duration" -- length outbreak (years) "n_df_start" -- number trees defoliated start "perc_df_start" -- percent trees defoliated start "max_df_obr" -- maximum number trees outbreak single year "yr_max_df" -- year maximum number trees defoliated "yr_min_ngsi" -- year lowest mean normalized growth suppression index (NGSI) "min_gsi" -- minimum growth suppression index "min_ngsi" -- minimum normalized gsi

title: Outbreak statistics — outbreak_stats

title: dfoliatR v0.3.0
text: Thanks contribution @MaxenceMartin @chguiterman added unit test, cleaned RCMD note, linting, Also updated function description new option {vdiffr} load Apply M1 machines, thanks @lionel- code example fix issue https://github.com/lionel-/ggstance/commit/eac216f6 Thanks @brews helpful resource: https://deanattali.com/blog/migrating-travis--github/ Thanks Ann Lynch Wojciech Kędziora suggestion. provide greater flexibility users looking defoliation causes growth suppression Removed ef_* data objects preference efk_* objects

title: dfoliatR v0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-09-02 Readme edits Edits function descriptions Adding new logo Fixed bug id_defoliation() regarding series_end_events Added updated East Fork data, new objects efk_* Fix plot_outbreak() flexible Y-axis labels shaded area Duration longer calculated series-end-events defol_stats() new factor, “se_outbreak” added outbreak() results identify ongoing events Duration statistics calculated ongoing events outbreak_stats() Add examples plotting functions dfoliatR now published Dendrochronologia

title: dfoliatR v0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-03-04 Edits DESCRIPTION Accepted CRAN

title: dfoliatR v0.0.4
text: preparation CRAN release adding examples primary functions checking spelling code format Updating man files usethis::use_roxygen_md() running diagnostic utilities devtools devtools::check() R CMD Check 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes devtools::check_rhub() 0 errors, 0 warnings, 1 note note relates spelling “Swetnam” “dfoliatR” DESCRIPTION. correct. devtools::check_win_devel() seems check . Update README Update pkgdown site

title: dfoliatR v0.0.39999
text: Add data Demi John; change built-data naming scheme help differentiate host series nonhost chronologies Added provision prevent defoliation events two years following one, unless bridge_events set true. Reduced event levels meaningful interpretation Added Gantt plot plotting options. required adding several new helper functions, including useful get_defol_events function Revised defol_stats catch series defol events Gantt plot now default tree-level plotting option Added unit tests defoliate outbreak functions plotting now stable ggplot2 v3.2.0 testing plots via vdiffr Add “Maturing” lifecycle badge Add new constructor functions (re)establish object classes defol outbreak. particularly useful batch processing {purrr} functions like map Changed outbreak object code obr. updated several functions account change. Bug fix get_defol_events() pass non-defoliated series final table. Spell check code flow fixes Added MIT License Adding Zenodo DOI Ready v.0.0.4

title: dfoliatR v0.0.3
text: Changed package name Add parameter allow events ongoing time sampling, called series end events. users know, certainty, sampling outbreak event. parameter allows events recorded regardless duration, recent end series. Add parameter allow bridging two defoliation events single tree. done observing instances two successive events separated single year, case western spruce budworm likely represented single, long event. option used caution scrutinized closely. Update author list reflect significant contributions dfoliatR development Ann Lynch Jodi Axelson. Replaced correct_host_series function gsi better capture process calculating growth suppression index.
